Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: The Role of Gravity Waves in Coupling Longitudinal Variations in the Troposphere to the Thermosphere and Ionosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a data analysis and modeling effort to be undertaken as part of the Coupling, Energetics and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions program. Atmospheric waves are one means by which energy and momentum can be transported between different layers of the atmosphere. Recent results show that the source of non-migrating tidal waves in the atmosphere -- the uneven distribution of deep cell convection zones in the troposphere associated with the land-sea contrast -- also gives rise to a varying source of atmospheric gravity waves. The main goal of this effort is to quantify this source and its potential effects, which is currently missing from models of the upper atmosphere and ionosphere and may force a revision in our understanding of how the apparent tidal signature in the ionosphere is driven by waves in the atmosphere. Global datasets of temperature and wind from satellite observations together with several advanced global atmospheric and ionospheric circulation models will be used to determine the spatial, temporal and spectral characteristics of large-scale gravity waves, their global effects on tidal variation, and the ionospheric impacts.

Gravity waves are a significant forcing source on Mesosphere-Lower Thermosphere (MLT) dynamics and their effects strongly impact general circulation and climate models. In addition, numerical weather prediction models, despite their tropospheric focus, have been shown to make better predictions when the upper-atmospheric dynamics are more accurately modeled. The work will be performed mainly by a post-doctoral scholar and a graduate student, both mentored by the principal investigator (PI), and in collaboration with data-analysis and modeling experts at Berkeley and at NCAR.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric waves are one of the principal means by which energy and momentum is transported between different layers of the atmosphere.  We now know that many types of these waves can propagate into space and change the conditions in the space environment around Earth. These waves change as they propagate upward, the main reasons for which are 1) interation with the flowing atmosphere, and 2) interactions with other waves. The prediction of conditions in space is fairly difficult, because these interactions are hard to measure directly or even fully simulate. This project focuses on a particular interaction of small-scale gravity waves with larger-scale tides, to try to understand if the space environmental effects of tides may actually originate with how gravity waves change the tides, rather than natural changes in the tides themselves.

Computer models that can capture the behavior of our weather and climate can simulate many of these waves, but for waves that are of very high wavelength like gravity waves emanating from thunderstorms and mountaintops, strategies have to be developed to make up for the lack of resolution and computer power to simulate every detail. For this project, the NSF-developed WACCM and TIMEGCM were used to simulate a year of atmospheric conditions, but informed specifically by observations of gravity waves by the NASA SABER instrument on the TIMED satellite. This was a significant effort that required 300,000 core-hours of processing on the new NSF Yellowstone supercomputer with remarkable results. We were able to simulate ionospheric conditions and thereby describe the impact of gravity waves in the space environment. The changes are significant but come indirectly, through their modification of the atmospheric tides. It is a remarkable indication of the connection of our troposphere to conditions in space.

The attached image one shows the indication of a gravity wave in the atmosphere from the stratosphere to the lower edge of the ionosphere (30-100 km). It can be seen in variations in the temperature as a function of altitude. Image two shows the total electron content in a TIMEGCM simulation, and the modification of the total electron content in the ionosphere by gravity wave modification of the space environment. The effects on TEC introduced by realistic gravity waves have amplitudes that are 10-20%, and vary on regional scales, showing regional impacts related to the distribution of sources of gravity waves in the troposphere.

In terms of broader impacts, improving representations of gravity waves in GCMs and understanding coupling mechanisms through gravity waves will likely have implications for studies of gravity waves at other planets, particularly Mars. Also note the recent science highlights of the Saturnian polar atmosphere and the remarkable wave features seen in that gas giant’s polar vortex. The impact on society is related to the advance of science and understanding of our planetary environment. Because waves are such an important topic in atmospheric physics, and waves are a commonly observed phenomenon that the general public can relate to, studies like this one inform the broader audience and citizen scientists so they can better participate in the discussion of humanity’s advance into space.
